description: Least nonnegative m such that n!-m is prime.
comments: Conjecture: for n >= 3, a(n) is 1 or a prime. - _Amarnath Murthy_, Mar 19 2002a(n) is not divisible by any prime <= n. If a(n) > 1 is composite, then a(n) > n^2. There are no entries up to n = 2000 with a(n) > n^2, and there may be none. - _Robert Israel_, Jul 20 2014
links: T. D. Noe and Hans Havermann (T. D. Noe to 500), Table of n, a(n) for n = 2..2000
Index entries for sequences related to factorial numbers
mathematica: p[n_] := Module[{nf = n!}, nf - NextPrime[nf, -1]]; Join[{0}, Table[p[n], {n, 3, 70}]] (* _Harvey P. Dale_, Jul 07 2012 *)
prog: (PARI) for(n=2,70, k=0; while(!isprime(n!-k), k++); print1(k,","))(PARI) vector(66, t, my(n=t+1, f=n!); f-precprime(f)) \\ _Joerg Arndt_, Jul 19 2014(Sage)def A033933(n):    if n < 3: return 0    f = factorial(n)    return f - previous_prime(f)[A033933(n) for n in (2..78)] # _Peter Luschny_, Jul 20 2014
author: _Jeff Burch_
